newsitem.title: USA: Asthmatic tenants blame bugs and landlord in NY.
newsitem.headline: Asthmatic tenants blame bugs and landlord in NY.

text.p: Tenants of a Bronx apartment building who link asthma-related problems to their landlord's alleged failure to rid their homes of cockroaches may file a class action lawsuit, their lawyer said on Friday.
Jayson Lutzky said he would pursue litigation against owners of the building "if there are enough complaints."

Residents of 264 East 199th Street were spurred to action by their former neighbour, Carmen Marty, 30, who filed a lawsuit Monday at Bronx Supreme Court on behalf of her two sons, Jonathon, 8, and Steven, 5. She is seeking $22 million for "painful personal injuries" and "emotional trauma" caused by frequent, severe asthma attacks that she said were triggered by the swarms of bugs roaming their previous home.

Last month, a study in the New England Journal of Medicine linked the rates of U.S. inner-city children with asthma to high levels of cockroach allergens. Marty's lawsuit was the first filed in New York based on this data, Lutzky said.

Marty, who said her sons' asthma improved when the family moved to a new apartment, told Lutzky that despite frequent complaints the 199th Street building owners, HKH Enterprises and Norwax Associates, had sent an exterminator to the building only twice in 10 years.
The companies were not immediately available for comment.
Since Monday, several of Marty's former neighbours, including a man who claims he lost part of his lung to asthma, have approached Lutzky about pursuing litigation, he said.
"Landlords are trying to get rid of rent control and raise rents but they don't spend money to fix apartments," Lutzky said. "I hope this sends a message that people have a right to safe apartments."
A few years ago, Lutzky won $20 million for a client who held his landlord accountable for vermin or insect bites on his testicles.
